title: The five most surprising college football recruiting classes

text:
Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook Email The five most surprising college football recruiting classes Big scores in unexpected places: Maryland, Pitt, Baylor, South Carolina, Mississippi State Post to Facebook The five most surprising college football recruiting classes Big scores in unexpected places: Maryland, Pitt, Baylor, South Carolina, Mississippi State Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/2jYF0ed Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs The five most surprising college football recruiting classes Paul Myerberg , USA TODAY Sports Published 1:44 p.m. ET Feb. 1, 2017 | Updated 6 minutes ago CLOSE x Share Here are the five best college football recruiting classes in the last decade of "National Signing Day". Maryland QB signee Kasim Hill. (Photo: Reinhold Matay, USA TODAY Sports) 
Here’s some bad news for those teams in the Football Bowl Subdivision not named Alabama, Clemson, Ohio State or Florida State, to name a few: Those teams that win on signing day – as in consistently sign classes inside the top 10 nationally – end up winning national championships. 
Thanks for playing, right? Not really. Across the FBS, teams are still putting together the sort of classes that may lead to championship contention, or at least compiling enough talent to challenge for an eventual berth in a New Year’s Six bowl. 
These teams are working somewhat under the radar, overshadowed by those high-profile rivals standing atop the team rankings on national signing day. But for five major-conference teams, Wednesday was a surprising success: 1. Maryland 
Top signees: CB Deon Jones, QB Kasim Hill, RB Anthony McFarland Jr. 
D.J. Durkin and his assistant coaches worked tirelessly to sign perhaps the nation’s most surprisingly effective recruiting class. Need to rebuild your roster? The Terrapins did just that in signing more than two dozen prospects from their own backyard — Maryland, Virginia and New Jersey — and as far away as California. It’s a hard road to the top of the Big Ten East Division, but Maryland took a drastic step forward. 
MORE SIGNING DAY NEWS 2. Baylor 
Top signees: WR Gavin Holmes, OL Xavier Newman, WR R.J. Sneed 
Baylor had just one verbal commitment when Matt Rhule was hired away from Temple in early December. Two months later, the Bears will sign a full allotment of 25 or more prospects, closing with a flourish despite Rhule’s newcomer status to Texas’ recruiting circles. It wasn’t the best class in the Big 12, but the past two months proved that Rhule and his staff have what it takes to match wits with the conference’s best. 3. South Carolina 
Top signees: WR OrTre Smith, WR Shi Smith, DE Javon Kinlaw 
The Gamecocks won battles with some of the region’s elite programs to sign a class that should finish inside the top 25 nationally. With help coming on the offensive line, at wide receiver and throughout the defense, this group will provide a strong foundation for a possible run at the SEC East Division title. It also puts to rest any questions the coaching staff’s recruiting ability. 4. Pittsburgh 
Top signees: OL Jerry Drake Jr., S Paris Ford, TE Charles Reeves 
Pat Narduzzi built his program in Michigan State’s image, so it’s not surprising to see the Panthers’ recruiting efforts mirror the same style used to such effectiveness by Mark Dantonio and the Spartans. While not necessarily brimming with top-100 talent, Pittsburgh’s class includes a nice blend of immediate assistance and prospects who should develop very nicely in Narduzzi’s system. 5. Mississippi State 
Top signees: LB Willie Gay, QB Keytaon Thompson, DT Deion Pope 
Take the Bulldogs’ class and compare it the group put together by rival Mississippi. That makes MSU’s group look even better, doesn’t it? While Hugh Freeze and his staff scuffled, the Bulldogs signed a borderline top-25 class, according to 247Sports.com. Heavy on junior-college help, MSU also inked in-state standouts in linebacker Willie Gay and running back Kylin Hill. 
HIGHLIGHTS FROM SIGNING DAY Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Marvin Wilson holds shoes after announcing he will sign with the Florida State Seminoles at Episcopal High School. Troy Taormina, USA TODAY Sports Natalie Pierce follows offers and pickups during national signing day at the University of Georgia's Butts-Mehre Heritage Hall. JOHN ROARK, AP Baylor head football coach Matt Rhule talks with reporters at a NCAA college news conference during national signing day. Rod Aydelotte, AP Auburn head coach Gus Malzahn speaks about his 2017 recruiting class during an NCAA college football news conference on national signing day. Julie Bennett, AP Greg Johnson and Joesph Lewis announce that they will sign with USC at Augustus Hawkins High School. Kelvin Kuo, USA TODAY Sports John Tyler High School football player Bryson Smith, center, is surrounded by family and friends on national signing day, Wednesday Feb. 1. Sarah A. Miller, AP Greenback High School football players, from left, Hunter Willis, Tennessee Tech; Kayne Roberts, North Carolina; and Tavin Kilpatrick, Tennessee Tech; pose for photos during national signing day. Tom Sherlin, AP Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh smiles as he sits on stage during the "Signing of the Stars" event on national signing day at Crisler Center in Ann Arbor. Melanie Maxwell, AP Lake Taylor High School football player Darnell Ewell commits to Notre Dame national signing day at Lake Taylor High School on Wednesday. Stephen M. Katz, AP Ty Chandler poses with his mother Katrina before signing with the Tennessee Volunteers at Montgomery Bell Academy during National Signing Day. George Walker IV, USA TODAY Sports Oak Ridge High School wide receiver Tee Higgins, surrounded by family and friends, looks on during a national singing day in Knoxville, Tenn. BRIANNA PACIORKA, AP Stephan Zabie poses with his adoptive family and Westlake athletic director and head football coach Todd Dodge (far right) after announcing his commitment to UCLA during National Signing Day at Westlake High School. Erich Schlegel, USA TODAY Sports Levi Jones poses with his sister Priscilla after announcing his commitment to the University of Southern California during National Signing Day at Westlake High School. Erich Schlegel, USA TODAY Sports Lee County High School defensive tackle Aubrey Solomon commits to the Michigan Wolverines during National Signing Day. Adam Hagy, USA TODAY Sports Montgomery Owen puts on a Washington and Lee University cap after signing his letter of intent to attend the school during a ceremony at Montgomery Bell Academy on National Signing Day.
